264.text: The picture which best sums up Vermeer’s

266.text:

one of the most famous works of art in the

270.text:
world. It has pride of place in Amsterdam’s
great Rijksmuseum; it is insured for perhaps

276.text:

282.text: Yet the painting is pointedly out of synch with its status. Because,

286.text:
above all else, it wants to show us that the
ordinary can be very special. The picture

292.text:
says that looking after a simple but beautiful
home, cleaning the yard, watching the children,

297.text:
darning cloth – and doing these things faithfully
and without despair – is life’s real duty.

303.text:
It is an anti-heroic picture: a weapon against
false images of glamour. It refuses to accept

309.text:
that true glamour depends on amazing feats
of courage or on the attainment of status.

314.text:
It argues that doing the modest things, that
are expected of all of us, is enough.

320.text:
Vermeer did not live long. He died in 1675,
still only in his early forties.

326.text:
But he had communicated a crucial – and
hugely sane – idea: much of what matters

331.text:
to us is not exciting, urgent, dramatic or
special things. Most of life is taken up dealing

337.text: with things that are routine, modest, humble, and (to be honest) a touch dull.

342.text: Our culture should focus on getting us to

345.text: appreciate the average, the ordinary and the everyday.

349.text:
When Vermeer painted his hometown
he didn’t choose a special day; the sky

353.text: is neither very overcast nor especially sunny.

355.text:
[View of Delft, 1660-1]
Nothing is happening. There are no celebrities around.

359.text:
Yet it is, as he has taught us to recognise,
all very special indeed.
